captions.text: All right.
Fine, Jackson, fine.

You told me all about
declawing and how terrible it.

Is And fine, fine, I
won't declaw my cat.

My cat is still
wrecking my house.

My cat is scratching
up my furniture.
My cat is scratching me.
I don't want my cat to scratch.
Now what do I do?

Well, calm down Sleepless
in Scratchville.
It's time to get catified.

If you watched episode
about declawing,

you know exactly where
I fall on the matter.

I mean, I made myself
pretty clear, right?
Don't do it.
Don't do it.

It's inhumane, it's cruel,
it's unusual, it's unnecessary.

And it rarely works in
solving behavioral problems.

It usually makes
other ones crop up.
And did I tell you it hurts?
You said, find.

And you said it in
loud, loud ways.

I mean, thank you
by the way, people.

The way you're coming out,
team Cat Mojo in force, right?

How do you live with
a cat and her claws?
Well, I'm going to tell you it.

There's a few things we
have to bear in mind.

Scratching is a
necessity for cats.
It's not a luxury.

Cats need to, first
of all, exercise
the top part of their body.

It's a nice way to grab
something and pull down and get
that exercise.

Also, it's a really important
part of marking territory.
Now remember, Cat Mojo 101.
Cats need to own places.

If they don't own places, they
become very, very insecure

and anxious, and they
act out in other ways.

If it is a necessary, if cats
do need to scratch, well then,

what are we going
to do about that?

The first thing that we
do is trim their nails.

You take either a nail trimmer
or a human nail clipper,

or the ones that they
sell in the stores that

are more like systems,
whatever suits your fancy.
You press the cat's pad.
And boink, out comes the nail.

All you've got to do
is take off the tip.

You don't have to
take off that part
where the red meets the white.

You don't have to worry
about hurting them that way.

You don't worry
about what we call

quicking them, which is
hitting that blood supply
and making everyone unhappy.
Just bump, and it's done.
It's also the approach, folks.

Just act as if you're just
walking up and you're say hi.

And things will get
much, much easier.
Also, catch them napping.

I mean, when your cat's
sleeping or just waking up,

you're having a lazy
moment together.

You can have clippers
by the side of your bed.

All you're doing is getting
the nail out and clipping.

If every time you
touch your cat's paws,
they're going to get clipped?

Then they're not going
to let you do it.

So associate it with positive
things, a nice quiet time.

And then maybe you
only get one nail
while you're sitting there.
That's fine.

Because over the course
of a couple days,
you'll get them all.

The next thing that we want
to start thinking about
is where they're scratching.

Remember, it's
territorially important.

There's two human scent
soakers-- your couch
and your bed.

Where do you spend the
most part of your time
when you get home from work?
Your couch and your bed.

And that's where
your scent is strong.
It's a scent soaker.

And because of that,
your cat is going

to want to compliment
your scent with theirs.

In the show, you've seen this,
I'm sure, a million times.
I get redundant.
The yes and the no.

Behind every no,
there has to be a yes.

If we don't want them scratching
on the arm of the chair,

we have to say, well, this
location is still important.

Let's say you use a
product like Sticky Paws.

Sticky Paws is
double-sided sticky tape

that is actually designed not
to actually stick to your couch.

But when your cat touches
it, it's kind of tacky
and they don't like it.

OK, we'll say no, and put sticky
paws down the arm of the couch.

But right next door, there
has to be a scratching post.

There has to be a scratching
post that works for them so

that they can compliment
your scent with them,

and leave a visual and scent
marker in a territorially
crucial area.

What makes a good
scratching post?

All right, let's
talk about that.

The first thing is
a nice wide base,

because if your cat goes to
scratch down and the thing

wobbles, well then,
the couch wins.

Does your cat prefer corrugated
cardboard or sisal rope
or carpeting or natural wood?
What is it your cat likes?

There are a lot
of nice scratches
out on the market there.

But you've got to sometimes look
in different places, you know?

You don't want to just go
for the first one you see,

and then get mad
when it doesn't work.

In a situation where
you have young children,

or if you're immune
compromised, things

like that-- which in the past
were kind of given reasons

to declaw a cat-- you can think
of something like Soft Paws.

And Soft Paws is a brand
name, but there are other ones
out there.

They're basically
just vinyl nail tips.
They go on.

They don't hurt,
nothing like that.

And the only downside is
that after a month or so,

they're just going to pop
off as the nail grows.

And then you trim the
nails and do it again.

It is a way that there's
no way that the nails can
do any damage.

I like that to be
sort of a last resort.
Because why do it?

Why go through all
the aggravation
if you don't have to?
Plus.

I like accommodating
the raw cat.

We want cats to be confident
in the areas that they scratch.

We want them to assert
themselves territorially.

We just want them to
do it in the place

that we want them to do
it, and not in the place
we don't want them to do it.

Don't forget, you can start
this when they're young.

I mean seriously, if you are
clipping your cat's claws

and giving them the yes and the
no, and they're a young kid,

you will not have a
problem as they grow up.

And there's a lot
of people out there

who are like, why would
I compromise for my cat?
You know, you've got children.
You've got spouses and partners.

And let me tell you
something, the compromise

involved with those guys
dwarfs the needs of your cat.

So listen, if you've got
to go out there and get

a scratching post, you've
got to put some sticky tape

on your couch, you've got
to go put Soft Paws on,

you've got to clip
your cat's nails.

That's the cost of having
a beautiful relationship
with your cat.

It is an invaluable
relationship,

and beautiful in
every single way.

Now you know everything
that you need

to know-- the basics,
anyway-- on making sure

that your furniture and
the people in your house

stay safe while keeping
your cat's claws intact.

Now, in the meantime folks, you
can find me anywhere, right?
Anywhere and everywhere.

Find me Twitter, Facebook,
InstaGram, Google+.
There's no excuse.
I am all over the place.

Be sure to join me on
Wednesday, February 5.
I'll answer your questions.

And we're going to talk
more about declawing.

So stay tuned for
more information.

But man, get that on your
calendar and do it now.

Hey, I've got to say
it one more time.

Folks, thank you so
much for the support

that you're showing that last
video that I put out there.

It's getting circulated
far and wide.
You are telling your friends.

We are finally going to
get that message out.
What's the message?
Declawing your cat is not OK.

Anyhow folks, until
we talk next time.

All light, all love,
all mojo to you.
Muah.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: How to Stop Your Cats From Scratching Furniture

comments.text:

comments.author: kyle “foxtrot101” pavlick

comments.text:
I'm so happy that I live in a country where de-clawing is illegal! 
I don't even agree with trimming, have never done it, and only ever would 
when the cat gets old and the tendons get weak. that's when they catch on 
carpet. 
Trimming may seem harmless but it makes it harder for the cat to strip off 
the dead outer layer of claw, and the soft part on the inner curve of the 
claw grows and hardens. This causes ingrowing claws. So if you trim, you 
MUST carry on trimming and inspect each claw every time you trim to make 
sure the underside is clear (you can scratch it off when it's still soft) 
and that the outer dead layer is removed. 
I took on a 9 year old cat whose claws were trimmed before, it took him a 
month or so to retract his claws fully and walk on carpet without snagging. 
I still check his claws and sure enough that soft stuff underneath needs 
scratching off every now and again. My other cat is also a rescue, 3 years 
younger and totally traumatised, non-handle cat (fine with stroking but 
cannot be restrained at all)
Between the two of them I have been scratched twice in two years, both 
accidental. 
My furniture is immaculate and I have told one once and the other 4 times - 
yes, in 2 years - never yelled, just said quietly no. They have 2 cat trees 
and 2 stand alone posts plus a cardboard scratcher, in an apartment less 
than 50 square metres. I don't pick them up and move them, no sprays, no 
yelling, nothing. I just treat them right and respect their felinity. I 
solve problems, I don't try to change the cat. The whole room is arranged 
so they can gt right around without touching the floor. The couch has a 
sheet over it and over the front to the floor and that's a den. 
Think cat!﻿

LOVE cats, they do not ever BARK, wake up neighbors or hump my leg! They 
aren't so big, needy and stinky. They let themselves in and out, wash 
themselves and often catch their own snacks now and then. They are 
relatively self sufficient coexistors in my home and I LOVE that.

Never declawed a cat in my life. I figured they came that way for a reason. 
Just like children, they need to be taught what is ok to scratch and what 
isn't. No big deal. The worst thing I've ever had since childhood were the 
big speakers that got shredded but they were gawdy anyways so who cares 
right?

Lol. A firm "no" and holding their paws to stop the scratching what I 
wanted them to not scratch but then immediately carried them to their 
scratch post and put their extended claws on that and it didn't take once 
or twice and they got the picture that this was their own scratch 
territory. It excited them that I had something special just for them to 
wreck lol.﻿

comments.text:
Thank you for emphasizing the relatively low cost of nail clipping and 
scratchers compared to the rewards of a good relationship with your cat. As 
a PetSmart liaison volunteer with the Nebraska Humane Society, the most 
common questions I'm asked by potential adoptive families are about claws 
and litter boxes. I get some weird looks when I suggest that you might have 
to literally get on your knees and use your own fingernails to demonstrate 
where it is ok for the cat to scratch, but then later I get the 'omg it 
worked!' and that always makes my day :)﻿

comments.author: zozek

comments.text:
It looks like you don't respond to comments often (which is completely 
understandable, you are a busy man) but perhaps one of your viewers can 
help me. My cat is 15, and was declawed when he was a kitten (my parents 
did it, I was in the 3rd grade and didn't know any better), is still 
destroying my furniture. The edges of my bed, the pillow top to my bed, the 
edges of the chest at the foot of my bed. He will paw and paw and paw and 
eventually the item will wear out. Sheets will rip, the edges of my bed are 
fraying, the corners of my chest are showing wood under the paint. He does 
sleep with me when I sleep, or lays with me as I crochet and watch tv, but 
he has his own bed he sleeps in too. The back side of his bed is a 
scratching board. It's bracketed into my cart (that he's made the bottom 
drawer of his bed) and I've changed it out to different things and he 
doesn't use it. I've tried carpet, cardboard, rope, a pillow, smeared 
catnip into it. He will not use the board, he uses everything else instead. 
How can I keep my 15 year old, declawed, cat (that acts like two year old) 
from wearing out my furniture? ﻿

comments.author: M Mosby

My landlord said I have to declaw my kitten. I don't want to do it. It just

comments.author: Weasleys Weezer

comments.text:
+Tara Cox You are such a zealot! Where did you get this BS about surgery 
without analgesia? That would be veterinary malpractice. Most declawing 
these days is done with lasers and with very appropriate anesthesia and 
analgesia both before, during and after, although not much is needed after 
as they don't experience much discomfort except the aggravation of having 
bandages, if used. They recover quickly, walk normally, continue to stretch 
using their "pads" as if they had claws, and some can even still climb 
trees since they mostly use hind claws to do this (although keeping them 
indoors will keep any cat alive a lot longer for many reasons). Cats 
practically never get arthritis, and when they do it is mostly in their 
hind legs, which are never declawed. I am not even going to try to convince 
you because you are so fixed in your beliefs, but either YOUR information 
source is biased/flawed, or you selectively remember what you need in order 
to try to convince other people of your immutable beliefs. 

Of course all alternatives should be tried first. But in those cases in 
which nothing can discourage a cat from destruction (and ultimate 
homelessness) I believe even Jackson might agree it is a rational solution. 
To threaten people (even in polemics) with what you imagine to be 
incapacitating surgery without analgesia is unbecoming an RN.
comments.author: Louise Andrew

comments.text:
+xNativeDreamsx Better yet, ask the land lord to have the the last joint of 
each finger and toe removed without analgesia. Then ask how the landlord is 
doing? Still able to type? Still walking without pain? Can they pull up a 
zipper, fasten a button? I very much doubt they would comply with your 
request. Best thing to do is educate people who are unfamiliar with what 
declawing actually entails, and explain the various options to protect 
furniture, and encourage scratching in appropriate places! Tara L.Cox
comments.author: Tara Cox

comments.text:
+Jellybean Frandsen Where do U get this stuff? How is amputating the last 
joint from the cats feet going to change the odors? FYI : "declawing is not 
just removing the nail, it removes a bone joint. This is a very painful 
procedure, almost always done without the administration of appropriate 
analgesia pre & post surgery. a cats needs to scratch it is a part of their 
natural activity to remove the scaling of the nails, to show emotions like 
excitement, anxiety, asking for attention. Cats walk on the tips of their 
toes, when the tips are amputated, it changes how they walk, which leads to 
stress on the joints of the foot/leg/shoulder & back and this causes 
arthritis, an inflammation of these joints. Research shows increased 
changes to cats behaviour post declawing: without their claws the will turn 
to biting as a defense mechanism, they can return home from the vet & not 
be able to tolerate the texture of the litter leading to urination outside 
the litter box. IF you have a cat, you NEED to EXPECT that they NEED places 
to SCRATCH. IF you VALUE your FURNITURE above your CAT, DO NOT BRING a cat 
into your home. People who keep cats learn to clip the cats nails, or they 
can apply rubber tips, but the nails still need to be clipped! Tara L. COX, 
RN
comments.author: Tara Cox

comments.text:
+Weasleys Weezer WHY is the landlord asking you to do this cruel & inhumane 
procedure? Please do not put your cat through this very painful procedure. 
Cats walk on the tips of their toes, this procedure cuts off the tips of 
their toes along with the nail, this is an amputation! Leads to increased 
pain with walking/scratching/litter avoidance, and ultimately arthritis in 
foot leg and back joints due to the changes to their ambulation. Take 
action & educate your landlord, and protect your cat from ignorant people. 
Tara L. Cox
comments.author: Tara Cox

comments.text:
+Jellybean Frandsen Your comments seem callous.......my opinion is they 
dehumanize KITTEHS, an animal that is very close to man!!! NO, claws 
are KITTEH-fingers.....try to understand how important they are!!!!!!!!!!
comments.author: tickyul

comments.text:
Never declawed anything in my life (nor shall I) but I'm sorry, they are 
not appendages they are considered a "nail" just the same as getting one of 
ingrowns removed for life and takes 6 full weeks to heal. My ex husband 
experienced no phantom pains for his toenails having been removed. I 
believe he would have really been upset if they had removed  his toenails 
at his elbows however. 

I take cats that have been declawed and they don't sit there and wallow in 
self pity over the loss of them. As a matter of fact one of my cats thinks 
shes and expert boxer and it's quite comical. There's no obvious pain over 
it.

As a matter of fact she's over it while this particular  avenue wishes to 
keep sobbing non stop  continuously over it. As for me, I'm kind of ready 
to move on actually. Everybody, do  what is right for  your animal as best 
as you know and quit judging others  for not following your set of 
standards.

comments.text:
+Sven Hassel Where do you get your information??? How can they not have 
complications from the amputation of the last joint of each toe? 1 cats 
walk on the tips of their toes, by removing the last joint it changes how 
they are able to walk, this leads to changes in the structure of the bone 
joints leading to arthritis. 2 with out claws to protect themselves, they 
turn to their only form of defense which is biting 3 declawing is a very 
painful procedure used to actually test new analgesia medication, but there 
is no standard of care setting which analgesia is best pre/post surgery, 
which leads many vets to not use appropriate pain medication, and other 
times no pain medication. Pain post surgery is the problem that leads to 
litter box issues, as the cat cannot tolerate the texture of the litter, 
leading to urination out side the litter box. Please do your research 
before your put such ignorant comments for all read, it really shows how 
uneducated you are and how inhumane & cruel a person you can be. Tara L. 
Cox, RN
comments.author: Tara Cox

comments.author: Kasia Karewicz

comments.text:
If my cat bit me when I was playing with her, I wouldn't play with her 
using any parts of my body, including my hands. For physical contact, I 
would be very still and pat her softly around the ears and neck, just 
enough, and stop when she begins to show irritation. A really fun way to 
play with your cat, and one she might like better, is to dangle something 
onto the floor, either a string, or something tied to a string, or 
something like that cat toy called "Da Bird." It looks like a fishing rod 
and line, and it has a fancy feathery bird at the end of the line, and you 
wiggle it on the floor so it looks (to the cat) like a bird walking along 
the ground, or make it wiggle on the floor like wounded bird. Then the cat 
will get its hopes up that there is a meal coming up, and will start 
creeping up on the bird, and when it gets closer, you lift the bird off the 
floor and make it fly around all over the place. You can even run around 
the house with it. Make sure you don't get the bird out of sight of the 
cat. Then you can let the bird slow down and land on the floor, and wiggle 
around, and watch the cat start getting ready to attack again, Once in a 
while, you let the cat catch the bird. Jackson Galaxy says "BE the bird!!" 
as you are controlling the bird in the air. This is really fun, when in 
your imagination, you pretend you are the bird, flying around escaping from 
the cat.  The cat does not care that she can't eat this bird, because she 
will have plenty of cat food to eat in your house, but cats love to hunt 
and catch. It's a very strong instinct in cats. When Jackson Galaxy says 
"Play with your cat," he means for you to do this getting the cat to hunt, 
stalk, pounce, capture, all with stuff at the ends of strings.  Then of 
course there are toys that run by themselves that cats can play with. They 
get excited by a wiggling toy.  A toy mouse can lie on the floor forever 
and the cat will ignore it, but as soon as you wiggle it, the cat's hunting 
instincts wake up.  I have a  hunch that your cat may bite you because 
he/she gets into the mood that you, your hand or arm or whatever you are 
moving is prey. So of course it's going to bite!!  And then it draws blood! 
Now you smell and taste like prey!! Be glad your cat is not as big as a 
tiger!!  Haha! 
So, I think if you abandon (leave behind) the idea of playing with your cat 
with your hand and your physical body in any way, and just play in this 
other way with soft toys on strings, you both will have more fun and you 
won't get hurt.  I like to put just a string with a little something soft 
tied to it, on the floor, and then try to make it wiggle as realistically 
as I can, so it really looks like a little mouse or bird. Really, watching 
them play like that is so much fun!!  They get into so many funny positions 
leaping around in the air!  This will give your cat much more exercise, 
too, than doing that thing where it winds up biting you.  Let us know if 
you try this and if it works! 

As far as scratching goes, just make sure you have a good scratching post, 
and if you can put up a cat tree, even better!!  Good luck! Oh, and you can 
probably find a video of Jackson playing with a cat, getting him to hunt 
something on a string.

comments.author: Kitty Sharts

comments.text:
Cats are—how do you say it?  Obligate Carnivores. They need to eat meat, an 
almost total meat diet. That vegan cat is going to slowly get sicker and 
sicker until she dies. If you Google this topic, you can find a lot of 
information about it and you can show your girlfriend. Of course, then it's 
up to her if she wants to ignore the truth and do it HER way.  But you can 
try to help poor kitty. My upstairs neighbors are vegetarians, because they 
are Sikhs (from India) but if they had a cat, they said, they would give it 
all meat. Cats do not have a choice, people do. Perhaps she should get a 
rodent of some kind. Guinea pigs, hamsters, mice. How about a rat? lol

Oh, and the kind of exercise a cat needs is not yoga. They already do that 
sort of yoga stretching anyway! For aerobic exercise, just get Da Bird or 
any kind of cat toys on strings etc and have a nice lively session of 
having the cat hunt down the prey!  Leap around the room!!  Then the cat 
will be full of joy and will get tired out and will be ready to settle down 
in her lap for nice cuddle!!  And remind her to not forget to add a 
scratching post—it is also a stretching post!!
comments.author: Wendalore65

Square Mile. Cats need to Run, Jump, Climb, Chase, Flee, Hunt, Kill, Eat, 
Sleep, to be really happy. Also feed them Feline favorites like Tuna, 
Swordfish, Sardines, Mackerel, Salmon (all can be found in the tuna section 
at the 99cent store). My cats world rather eat fish sticks than most of the 
garbage they sell at the pet store..﻿

comments.text:
+EPIC TACOZ SORRY to disagree, but I believe that there is no good reason 
to declaw a cat. Declawing is cruel & inhumane because it is an amputation 
of the final joint of each toe. Better to revisit the discussion with the 
landlord, clarify why they made this request, counter with education of 
what declawing entails & the various post op complications, along with the 
various options to give the cat to scratch in appropriate places along with 
regular nail clipping & nail tips. If none of this helps, you can choose to 
move or you may not be an appropriate cat companion. T.L. Cox
comments.author: Tara Cox

comments.author: zozek

comments.text:
We had this situation with 3 cats we had owned for their whole lives.  We 
were starving students,  given an apt rent free for the summer while we 
volunteered medical services in an underserved area.  Unfortunately, the 
place had an IRRESISTABLE nubbly sofa.  We had no good alternative---give 
up our babies, render them harmless, or quit the volunteer job and go 
home.  We had all  of them (Siamese) declawed by a local vet.  They all 
recovered in about a day, and after the bandages were off never noticed 
that they didn't have claws.  Still exercised their digits on the sofa, but 
it did no harm.  One still could climb trees when she slipped outside on 
occasion.  But we kept them in, so no problem with predators.  And they 
loved each other, so no need to defend from themselves.  They all lived to 
be close to 20 years old, were affectionate, loyal, TALKATIVE and hassle 
free pets.  Oh yes, and they also all used the toiletl  Which was very 
helpful as we completed medical training and were absent for days while at 
the hospital.  Although I love Jackson, I think he is a bit "dog"matic at 
times.  So are many of his followers.  No one answer fits all.
comments.author: Louise Andrew

comments.author: Kaleigh Curry

comments.text:
Though I've always previously been a "rescue" cat owner, I was fortunate 
that my first (and so far only) breeder cat came from a breeder that 
included (no option) a great scratching post that the cat was raised on 
with purchase and required a "no declaw" contract. I don't trim my cat's 
claws since he is allowed outside and I want him to have all his defenses 
intact, but I still handled his paws from day one just in case and have not 
had him scratch my furniture once. He has one pillar on our backyard porch 
that has an impressive set of claw marks to define his territory; the 
scratching post that came from the breeder is in my bedroom and I have a 
cardboard incline scratching platform in my living room.﻿
comments.author: Carol Melancon

comments.text:
Strangely, when my rescue cat arrived into the house he would scratch in 
hidden places such as behind the laundry line. Well I fixed the issue with 
a lot of scratching posts with catnip, together with lavender oil on the 
places he scratches that are not allowed (acting as repulsive). Clipping 
nails is still complicated: he allows the paws to be touched but if I touch 
the claws he fights back. Well, one claw at a time, the slow and steady 
wins the trimming argument :)﻿
comments.author: MollyStork

comments.text:
If you don't wanna do that, here is a better solution that will also make 
the world a better place.

Shoot your cat........ Get a dog........

Have you noticed that in the movies, the dogs are good, and the cats are 
bad?
And have you noticed that the dogs actually feel affection for you?
And have you noticed the cats don't give a crap?﻿
comments.author: Collin Craven

comments.text:
+Amber Barton I'm glad to read about how much you like cats and appreciate 
them so much. I used to be a dog person, too. In fact, I just became a cat 
person!!  But I don't agree with some of the generalizations you make about 
dogs and the differences between cats and dogs and the reasons cats are 
"better" connected with their genetics. For example, it is hard wired into 
dogs to be domesticated, and that is hardwired into cats, as well. 
Otherwise, they would be just like small lions and tigers, which they are 
not!  The biggest difference in the behavior of cats and dogs in famillies 
is that wolves (ancestors of dogs) lived and hunted in packs, so they HAD 
to be more cooperative with each other. Felines are solitary hunters 
(except for lions in a pride.) You can tell they are used to living around 
other felines because they are so territorial with each other. I'd say cats 
tend to like each other, but only if they respect each other's territories. 
( I learned something from "My Cat From Hell" recently. He came into a home 
in which one cat was dominating the other cat like crazy and the victim cat 
was peeing all over the floor and hiding the rest of the time. Jackson 
didn't do anything with the aggressive cat. He did a serious of things with 
the victim cat to turn him into a "confident cat" and then, as a "confident 
cat," he stood up for himself with the aggressive cat, and territory got 
balanced, and the victim cat completely stopped peeing on the floor! I was 
really surprised that it was not a matter of re-training the aggressive 
cat. It was funny, too. The aggressive cat was this pale long-haired sweet 
looking ball of fluff. The victim cat was a large sleek black and white 
cat!!

 I think it would be interesting if someone did a study on the differences 
in personality between dog people and cat people, as you mentioned that you 
do see a difference.  I think cat people can recognize their cat's 
individuality and how it makes choices—and, after all, being so small, they 
are more sensitive and can't take as much roughousing (well, small dogs are 
more sensitive, too, aren't they?) and dog people when they see that, think 
that the cat doesn't care about the person and it is aloof.

I prefer it when people don't say that cats are better than dogs or dogs 
are better than cats. I think it totally depends on the preference of the 
owner. Also, another important thing that makes a difference is whether a 
dog or a cat was abused when young. Just like with people, it's very hard 
to get beyond that suspiciousness and lack of trust which they learned from 
being abused.

Here's something we could notice here online, on cat or dog discussions. 
Which people tend to post angrier posts, cat people or dog people.  Did you 
ever notice? I didn't—I just know there's a lot of unnecessary anger 
between people with different tastes.  And the reason I thought of that, is 
that I think these extremely angry people were abused as children. Maybe 
not physically abused, but a lot of disapproval and criticism.
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
Maybe that's true in the movies, but in reality, cats usually care very 
very much for their owners. The relationship between a gentle and caring 
owner and a sweet cat is a beautiful thing.  When you see images of people 
holding their cats, and the cat is very relaxed with its eyes half closed, 
that is a cat that is feeling love.  Of course, if an owner is cruel or 
rough with the cat, the cat will not love them.
comments.author: Wendalore65

comments.text:
My dog has an anti-social, non-loving, mean, "don't give a crap" 
personality whereas my cat snuggles with me, kisses me, follows me around, 
answers to her name, purrs and loves on me constantly, is the sweetest 
animal I've ever owned (and I've owned many dogs growing up) and I wouldn't 
trade her for the world.  And this is coming from someone who grew up and 
loved (and still does love) dogs their whole life until I got my first cat 
and that completely changed my opinion of cats.  I would rather have a cat 
over a dog ANY day.  Their independent but also loving because they CHOOSE 
to be not because it's hardwired in them to be dependent on humans. 
 They're fine defending themselves and will bring you gifts showing they 
care as well as respect you more than ANY dog I've ever had has respected 
me (aside from my border collie but she acted more like a cat if I'm being 
honest) and from my experience cat people and dog people are very different 
just as cats and dogs are.  Cats take time to grow to you, they need to 
learn to trust you, and develop a relationship over time and dogs are just 
immediately and blindly loyal and needy and have to be taught everything. 
 Cat people value that animal's individuality and independence and respect 
it as they do their owners and it transcends into life where they value 
relationships that take time and trust to develop instead of blindly 
trusting whoever they meet like dog people tend to do.  This is just from 
what I personally have seen and experienced in my life from being a dog 
person as a child and then a cat person at the current place in my life now 
and I see it a lot in people who are cat/dog people.  Dog people tend to 
like being depended on hence why they like dogs.  Dogs need that constant 
guidance and attention and someone who's going to lead them because they 
lack independence and they lack their own ability to realize right from 
wrong.  I just prefer how cats are more intelligent and have vast and 
complex personalities and take time to love you because that time you spend 
and let grow with the cat is so worth it in the end.  More loyal than any 
dog because they take the time to get to know you as well.
comments.author: Amber Barton

comments.text: Collin, you can leave and live in your ignorant bliss.
comments.author: joyjoyoo

comments.text:
Have you even watched his videos? You will find an answer to your ''have 
you noticed the cats don't give a crap''. I am totally a dog person! But I 
also have cats, and I can say they are also VERY sociable creatures, they 
are kind and affectionate.

You know, it's an horrible thing to say ''shoot your cat''. Shooting an 
animal or any living being is a horrible thing, you shouldn't say that..
If people prefer cats, it's fine! Get a dog, and live on!

also, in the movies? Alright, we better all start living our lives by the 
standards of movies!
